summary: The most likely first component of cells to exist would have been the cell membrane. The membrane was just a thin layer surrounding an empty cell interior. However, that ancient cell membrane is almost indistinguishable from those of the cells in our bodies. Topic 2.3 is about the cell membrane and all the unique bits and bobs that make it work.

vocab.definition: Describes the cell membrane as a dynamic structure composed of a lipid bilayer with embedded proteins, carbohydrates, and cholesterol, where components are in constant, fluid motion
Lipids which contain a hydrophilic head and hydrophobic tail and make up cell membranes
Structure of all biological membranes, consisting of two layers of phospholipid molecules arranged with their hydrophilic heads facing outward and their hydrophobic tails facing inward
Specialized proteins that are embedded in or associated with the cell membrane that play roles in cell structure, signaling, and transport
Proteins embedded into the phospholipid bilayer that have hydrophobic and hydrophilic regions and which pass through the entire membrane (also called transmembrane proteins)
Proteins attached to the surface of the phospholipid bilayer that are not embedded into it and only face one side of the membrane
A protein with one or more carbohydrate chains, often located on the surface of the phospholipid bilayer, playing a crucial role in cell signaling, recognition, and the immune system
A molecule consisting of a lipid and carbohydrate, located on the surface of the phospholipid bilayer, playing a crucial role in cell signaling, recognition, and the immune system
The principal steroid; used in animal cell membranes
